clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of a Personalized Intervention in Gait Velocity and Functionality in Diabetic Neuropathic Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of a Personalized Intervention by a Software in Gait Velocity, Biomechanics and Functionality of Foot and Ankle in Diabetic Neuropathic Patients: a Randomized Controlled Trial.

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

collaborator.agency: Coordenação de Aperfeiçoamento de Pessoal de Nível Superior.

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The main objective of this trial is to investigate the effects of a personalized intervention of exercises for the ankle-foot complex, supervised by a physical therapist and also via software, in gait velocity of patients with diabetic neuropathy.

detailed_description.textblock:
A randomized controlled trial will be performed with 46 patients with diabetic neuropathy. The participants will be randomly assigned into either a control group (recommended foot care by international consensus with no exercises) or an intervention group which will receive 12-week physical therapy exercises, twice a week, under the supervision of a physiotherapist, and twice a week being remotely supervised by a software at home. Every exercise has its own progression depending on the subjects' execution, increasing in intensity and difficulty.
The subjects will be evaluated in 5 different moments. The self-selected walking speed will be investigated with photocells and the incidence of foot ulcers will be registered on a web software during one year in a longitudinal study. Through force platform and infrared cameras, the kinetics and kinematics during gait will allow assessment of joint moments, power during propulsion, and foot and ankle range of motion.
The hypothesis is that the personalized exercises for the ankle-foot complex via software will increase the self-selected gait speed, reduce incidence of plantar ulcers and their risk, increase health and functionality of the feet, increase feet strength and ankle isometric torque, maintain temperature of the feet, and produce beneficial biomechanical changes during gait.

primary_outcome.description: self selected shod walking velocity in a walkway

secondary_outcome.description: Score of the classification of the plantar ulcer risk (IWG diabetic foot)
Score of the Foot Health Status questionnaire - BRAZIL
Hallux and lesser toes force measured by a pressure plate
Flexor and extensor ankle isometric torque
mean foot temperature, temperature difference and normalized temperature by a thermographic camera

secondary_outcome.measure: Foot and ankle Kinematics during gait
secondary_outcome.description: Foot joints and plantar arch motion, ankle range of motion, and maximum ankle extension and flexion during gait

secondary_outcome.measure: Ankle and Knee joint moments and power during gait
secondary_outcome.description: Peak joint moment and eccentric and concentric power by inverse dynamic calculations

arm_group.description: Patients will receive a physical therapy intervention in groups twice/wk, and using a software twice/ wk for 3 months.
Patients will not receive any exercise treatment, will not have acess to the software, but they will keep their recommended clinical treatment.

intervention.description: Patients will receive a physical therapy intervention in groups twice/wk, and using a software twice/ wk for 3 months, for foot and ankle strengthening, stretching and functional training. They must continue to exercise at home twice a week with the software supervision for one year.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diabetes mellitus type 1 or 2
- Moderate or severe polyneuropathy confirmed with the fuzzy software
- Body mass index ranging 18.5-29.9 kg/m2 (normal and overweight classifications)
- Ability to walk independently in the laboratory
- Accessibility to electronic devices
- Loss of at least 4 degrees of ankle range of motion or 20 degrees of the first metatarsophalangeal joint
- Loss of at least 1 degree of force in the clinical scale of the plantar interosseous or lumbrical muscles
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ulceration not healed for at least 6 months
- Hallux amputation or total amputation of the foot
- Receiving any physiotherapy intervention or offloading devices
- Neurological or orthopedic impairments
- Major vascular complications
- Severe retinopathy
